Title: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Retrolaminar Block and Serratus Anterior Plane Block for Postoperative Analgesia in Radical Mastectomy

Background: The retrolaminar block (RLB) is a newly introduced regional anesthetic technique for radical mastectomy. Its efficacy compared to the serratus anterior plane block (SAPB) is not well established.

Methods: This prospective, randomised controlled trial was conducted with 70 patients undergoing radical mastectomy. Participants were randomly assigned to receive either ultrasound-guided RLB or SAPB. The primary outcome was the visual analogue scale (VAS) score during coughing at 6 hours postoperatively. Secondary outcomes included dermatomal spread of sensory block, intraoperative hemodynamic changes, and analgesia-related adverse reactions. Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment. Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments.

Results: Seventy patients were randomised, with 35 allocated to each group. The median VAS scores during coughing at 6 hours postoperatively were 2 (IQR: 1-3) in both groups, indicating no significant difference (P = 0.39). RLB provided broader sensory coverage on the medial side of the nipple compared to SAPB (median [IQR]: 3 [3-4] vs. 2 [1-2], P = 0.006). No significant differences in mean arterial pressure or heart rate were observed immediately or 5 minutes after skin incision. The incidence of adverse events did not differ significantly between the two groups.

Interpretation: Both RLB and SAPB provide comparable postoperative analgesia following radical mastectomy, with RLB offering a broader sensory block range, particularly over the medial chest wall. Trial registration: [Trial registration number]. Funding: [Source of funding].
